text.headline: Rev. J.H. Magee in the midwest, 1839-1864
text.text:
James H. Magee (1839-1912) was born to free parents in Madison County, Illinois, where his family worked as tenant farmers. After discrimination forced him out of the local school, he traveled to Racine, Wisconsin, where he was allowed to continue his education. This sparked a lifelong interest in learning that took Magee to Cincinnati, Toronto, and London, before settling in Springfield, Illinois, as a minister, school teacher, and activist for African American suffrage and education.  

Book excerpts from: Night of affliction and morning of recovery: an autobiography, 1873. text.headline: Louisville, Kentucky, Early 1800s
text.text:
"My parents were born in Kentucky. My father was what is called 'free born,' but my mother was not so fortunate. She was born a slave, belonging to Billy Smith, of Louisville. My mother, being a slave, naturally prevented her uniting with my father in marriage until he had paid what her owners were pleased to term her equivalent in money. 

"The sum was set; he began to make strenuous efforts to raise the required amount. He had a great reputation as a pork packer, in which capacity he worked several seasons. I have heard him say that he has worked all day, stopping just time enough to take his supper, and then set in again for the night, working till day-light in the morning; and so on for weeks. Finally the sum for which he so ardently sought was raised, and paid over to Mr. Smith, after which they were united in marriage."

--The Night of Affliction and Morning of Recovery: An Autobiography View at Internet Archive

text.headline: Madison County, Illinois, 1839
text.text:
"My brother was successful in purchasing a site for a farm containing one hundred acres, twenty of it being in timber. William, Alfred, and Samuel Magee went immediately to breaking the prairie, preparatory to removing to it... We remained on that farm two years, we then removed to our own prairie home. Prosperity shone upon our pathway for several years, God blessing the labors of the family most abundantly."

--The Night of Affliction and Morning of Recovery: An Autobiography View at Internet Archive

text.headline: Brooklyn, Illinois, mid-19th C
text.text:
"I was delighted at the idea of going to school -- the place I had often heard of but never seen... I was sent to the Brooklyn district school, to which I went for some considerable time. At length prejudice began to show itself on the part of the parents of some of the children, which was communicated to the trustees. Many of the parents of the children were perfectly willing that I should go to school with their children, but there were others who thought their children were too good to go to the same school with a colored person. The trustees thought it best, for peace sake, to have my parents withdraw me."

--The Night of Affliction and Morning of Recovery: An Autobiography View at Internet Archive

text.headline: St. Louis, Missouri, 1862
text.text:
"I placed myself on the table, the doctor began to probe my limb, I began to scream, from pain, he cried: 'give him the chloroform!'... At last the incision was made, the forceps applied, and a portion of decayed bone drawn out. But there was a piece of bone, which seemed unyielding, to remove which the doctor had to take a small chisel and hammer, and break it into pieces...

"At the expiration of thirty minutes it was all done, the limb bound up, and many of the doctors preparing to leave. I looked around and saw the doctor replacing his lancets, knives, etc. I felt exceedingly happy, happy to know that I had survived the terrible operation."

--The Night of Affliction and Morning of Recovery: An Autobiography View at Internet Archive

text.headline: Springfield, Illinois, 1864
text.text:
"My little brother Lenard had been persuaded to leave his home, to go into the army as a substitute for one of our neighbors. The dastardly act was accomplished by this man, whose name I will not mention, and his accomplices. This event nearly distracted my aged mother, in so much, that she appeared completely overcome with grief. Her grief was aggravated by the taunting remarks of the poor cowards, that 'it does not make any difference, it is only a n-----.' This shows how much wickedness and cowardice they were possessed of."

--The Night of Affliction and Morning of Recovery: An Autobiography View at Internet Archive
